turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: We'll hear argument first today in Maryland versus Blake.
Ms. Graeff.

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
In Edwards versus Arizona, this Court held that a suspect has a choice, after invocation of the right to counsel, to change his mind and initiate further contact with the police.
The question in this case is whether that choice should be taken away, and a suspect's decision to speak presumed involuntary, when a police officer first makes an improper comment.
The answer should be no when the impropriety is cured.

When, under all of the circumstances, a reasonable person in the suspect's position would understand that it was the suspect's choice whether to speak or remain silent and that the police would honor that choice and stop questioning, a decision to speak should be deemed initiation, under Edwards.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Now, what has to be considered, by way of evidence, in evaluating whether the suspect has initiated the additional conversation?
Is it appropriate, in this case, to consider the age of the person?

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: Yes.
I think you would look at a reasonable person in--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And--

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --the suspect's--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --and the fact that, on the charges which he saw, it said he was subject to the death penalty, but that was not correct?

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --That would go to whether the statement was voluntary, it would not go to--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: It would not--

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --the degree--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --you would not consider it in connection with the initiation--

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --No, the--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --question?

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --No, the purpose of Edwards was to prevent police badgering.
To prevent police conduct that, conveys, directly or indirectly, that the police are going to continue questioning until they get a statement, despite the invocation of the right to counsel.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, I--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Counsel--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --I suppose that if they knowingly put death on in order to get him off his balance, that would be badgering, wouldn't it?

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: The... the purpose of Edwards was to prevent police questioning.
So, when a curative measure conveys that, the police are not going to question any longer.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, but--

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: The--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --the initial question Justice O'Connor asked is, Do we consider these other factors?
And then... but you're talking now about curing.

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --And my answer is no, that we do not consider what... the death sentence.
There's two.
In Bradshaw--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Then why consider age?
I mean, the... both of them go to the same point, and that is, What would a reasonable person suppose the suspect's understanding was at that point?
And would it be fair to conclude that the suspect was, in fact, initiating conversation, rather than responding to the police or doing something irrational?

And I don't see why the... in effect, the false statement about the death penalty... or true statement about the death penalty, for that matter... doesn't go to the same point, just as the suspect's age goes to it.

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --Because the critical inquiry is whether the suspect understood that it was his choice and that the police would stop questioning.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But the--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: So, the--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --but the trial judge made certain findings.
He heard these witnesses.
He heard the police officers.
And he suggested that the... Police Officer Reese was playing a good cop/bad cop game with Detective Johns.
And so, that this... the statement made by Reese,
"You'll want to talk to us now, huh? "
was designed to elicit an answer.
And the trial court also said there is an additional factor, and that is this charge, that was intimidating even if it didn't have death on it, wasn't presented to Blake immediately.
It could have been presented when he was put in the cell, initially.
So, there were those factors.
Those are relevant, are they not, to the character of what Blake said?

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: I think what... you look at... the relevant factors are the factors that go to whether a reasonable person would understand that questioning was going to stop.
This Court has said that there were two--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: What about the factors that I mentioned?

Would they be relevant to a factfinder's determining what a reasonable person in that situation... with the two police officers appearing, with the charges not being presented immediately, not being presented at the time the Miranda warnings were given, but only after... would those be... would those be relevant factors to decide if this was a voluntary initiated request to talk to the police?

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --No, because I think what you're looking at is not voluntariness.
You're looking at knowing.
Did this suspect know that the questioning was going to stop?

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, but it--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --Yes, but you're--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --it has to be--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --you're making--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --voluntary at some... if you held the man's hand to a burning iron, we would... we'd say that's not voluntary.

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: It's involuntary.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: So, it has to be voluntary, certainly, in the lay sense of the term.
Then the law has certain accretive force when we talk about, you know, involuntary as a matter of law.

But what we're... what we're talking about, it seems to me, is, rather, a commonsense inquiry as to whether or not it was voluntary, as to which I don't think you necessarily lose your case, but it seems to me that at least these have to be considered in determining whether or not it's voluntary.

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: Well, I think that's the second step of the analysis.
The first step of the analysis, which is what this case is... before the Court is, on initiation.
Now, voluntariness--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, but I... you can't initiate something involuntarily and have that count, can you?
You say--

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --Our--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --let's say involuntarily, in the lay sense of the word, in the common sense of the word, where it was actually physically coerced.
That wouldn't count.

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --It would be an involuntary statement under the second--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --step of the analysis.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --No, but what about--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: No, no, it's the--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --the first step?

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --first part of the analysis.

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: In the first part of the--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: How--

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --analysis, our--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --The first part of the analysis is whether or not he initiates.

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: And you're trying to tell us that the initiation can be involuntarily?
I just don't... I just don't agree with that.

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: Well, what we're trying to say is that the purpose of Edwards was to prevent badgering, where the police convey--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --All right.
But suppose the police are twisting his arm behind his back until he initiates a further discussion.
You would say that's fine?

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: I mean, you have to concede--

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --Well, if they're twisting their back, you're not thinking they're going to stop questioning.
I mean, what you're looking--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: No, you're--

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --at is, Did--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --Aren't you... aren't you confusing Miranda, which is a question of comprehension followed by voluntary waiver, with the question of initiation?
They are separate questions.
And what our... what we are trying to get at is: If there is going to be an initiation on the suspect's part, doesn't it have to be a voluntary initiation?
Your answer consistently is, Did he know that questioning would stop?
And those are two different issues.
One is understanding Miranda warnings.
One is voluntarily initiating a further conversation with the police.
So, I don't see it... let's assume he perfectly understood the Miranda warnings.
But if the initiation was not a voluntary initiation, or an initiation at all, it seems to me you lose.

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --Well, Maryland's position is that if you look at the analysis in Elstad and Seibert, where what this Court said is, you don't look at whether something caused something else, you look at whether there was a cure in the sense that the suspect understood his rights--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Ms. Graeff, is there any case which says that an initiation is not voluntary, as opposed to a confession being not voluntary, because the suspect has been charged with a crime greater than what the police believe they can prove, or if the police advise him that he's been charged with a greater crime than what he's really been charged with?
Is there any case which says that the effect of that is to cause his initiation of discussion to be involuntary?

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --Not that I'm aware of.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Do you take--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --the position that initiation is a purely formal inquiry, a matter of magic words?
If he says the equivalent of,
"I guess I'll talk to you. "
that's all you look at?

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: What you look at as, in Seibert, is, Was he--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: No, but ask--

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --given a genuine choice?

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --answer my question.
Is that all you look at?

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: You look at whether he understood that the questioning was going to cease, and it was up to him--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: No, you're--

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --whether to speak.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --you're avoiding my question.

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: My question is, Is the act of initiation a purely formal act on your view, so that so long as the suspect says the magic words, it doesn't matter what is in his mind or what he understands?
Is it formal or not formal?

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: It's not formal.

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: What you need to look at is whether an objective person in the suspect's position would understand that questioning was going to cease, and there was... would be no more questioning.
Edwards--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --But, can I interrupt with--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --I think we can--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --with one--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --I think that's a given.
The question is whether or not he agrees... he indicates affirmatively that he wants to begin talking.

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --And here, there's no question he wanted to--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: That's--

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --begin talking.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --the issue, it seems to me.

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: And there's no question here that he wanted to begin talking.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: All right, now suppose... I don't understand all these legal terms here.
Imagine.
[Laughter]
It may be close to the truth.
Now, we have a case, a hypothetical.
The defendant is sitting there, the police say, "Question"?
And he says,
"I want to see my lawyer. "
And the policeman says the following,
"That's fine, go ahead, we'll get him. "
"By the way, if you see him, we'll execute you. "
"Are you sure you don't want to talk to us? "
That's plainly unlawful, isn't it?

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: Involuntary.
Under--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Fine.

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --the second step--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Now--

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --of the--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --Now--

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --analysis--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --Now, the same thing happens, but what he says is,
"You'd better talk to us, or you'll be executed. "
"Think about it. "
Equally unlawful, right?

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --It would be involuntary--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --under the second--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Now, a minute--

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --test.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --passes while he's thinking about it.
Okay?
Is it... is it unlawful now, because a minute has passed before he says yes?

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: It would make it unlawful... unvoluntary.
But, again--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I just--

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --with... There's a two step process.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --I don't... I don't want legalism.
I just want the conclusion.
A minute has passed before he says yes.
Has that changed everything, and it becomes lawful?

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: No.
Now it's 15 minutes.
Now it's 30 minutes.
Okay?
Now, a court says 30 minutes is the same as one minute,
"We don't think the passage of 29 extra minutes made a difference. "
And what's your reply?
Not in legalism.
You're going to say,
"Oh, no, the passage of 30 minutes, rather than 1 minute, makes all the difference. "
And I would like to know why.

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: Actually, our position is more Detective Johns' actions rather than... the passage of time was a factor, but the more significant--

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --thing here--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --Yes, that's fine.
I'm not... I'm... I want you to say that kind of thing.
You're saying it's not just 30 minutes, it's "also some other things happened".
What?

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --Significantly, Detective Johns' conduct and his words, when... when Office Reese made the improper statement, Detective Johns immediately and firmly--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: The--

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --reprimanded--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --improper statement was,
"I bet you want to talk now, huh? "

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Right?
And--

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --immediately, the other detective, Johns... immediately?

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: Yes.
Immediately--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Said what?

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --immediately said,
"No, he doesn't want to talk to us. "
"He already asked for a lawyer. "
"We cannot talk to him now-- "

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So, that's--

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --and pushed him.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --possible.
That definitely cuts in your favor, unless, of course, it sounds like a good cop/bad cop routine.
And--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: There was--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --people--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --there was no finding that this was a good cop/bad cop--

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --routine, was--

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: In fact--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: In fact, there was a finding that Johns' testimony was credible.

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --Yes, that Johns' testimony was credible, and that Johns did not intend this to happen.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --But that's--

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: This was--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --subjectively true.
And so, I'd simply wonder if the fact that it's subjectively true, and there is a finding that the defendant... here, we have 30 minutes, and we have the fact that the other detective said,
"He said he can't talk to us. "
"We can't do anything about it. "
We have that.
Is there anything else?

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --We have that Detective Johns then pushed him out of the cell--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --and they left.
So the police initiation was terminated.
And--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --then when Detective Johns came back, 28 minutes, he didn't say anything.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: He didn't ask any questions.
And it was Blake who initiated and said, clearly, he wanted to talk to the police.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: All right.
Right.
So--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --May I ask--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --we have a passage--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --May I ask you two rather elementary questions?

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: One of the issues is whether... when he spoke and said, "Can I talk now"?
--was that voluntary or not?
Who has the burden on whether it was, or not, voluntary, the State or the defendant, in your view?

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: The state has the burden to show that he initiated.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And so, the State did have the burden.
And what is your view on the fact that the trial... the judge who heard the evidence said they had not met the burden?
What kind of deference is owing to that finding?

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: We think none, because the trial court did not focus on the proper analysis.
The trial court focused on a causal connection analysis that this Court has--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: May I--

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --rejected in Seibert--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --May I... before we get to that, I read the trial court's opinion, and it didn't seem to me that it was playing, as Justice Breyer said, this game of legal words and labels.
It was saying,
"There are things to suspect here. "
"Yes, I credited Detective Johns. "
"But he was asked, 'Why did you bring along Reese? "
"You didn't need him? "
And there was no answer to that.
And there was also no explanation, after they left Blake in his cell, Reese just having said,
"I bet you want to talk to us now, huh? "
--there was nothing said to assure Blake that that was not a
"You'd better talk to us, or you're going to be in trouble. "
kind of thing.
There was just the statement by Blake and another Miranda warning.
All of those things, the judge said, weighed on his mind, and he reached the conclusion that the Government hadn't sustained its burden on the basis of those factors.
So, is that clearly erroneous?
I mean, don't we defer to the judge's findings?

turn.speaker: kathryn_grill_graeff
turn.label: Ms. Kathryn Grill Graeff
turn.text: --If the inquiry is a... clearly erroneous, yes.
But our position is that whether or not there was initiation is a mixed question of fact and law, whether a reasonable person would understand the questioning was going to stop.
And so, when you look at this reasonable person analysis, you don't give deference to the findings of the lower court.
And if I could reserve the rest of my time, if there are no more questions.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --Thank you, Ms. Graeff.
Mr. Feldman.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
An improper question or comment under Edwards can be cured if the police terminate the questioning and make it clear to the suspect that they will honor his decision whether or not to talk to them--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, tell us--

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --without counsel.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --what factors, in your view, can be considered.
The--

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: I think--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --The defendant's age?
The improper charge?
What else can be considered?

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --I think all of those things can be present in any Miranda case, and are taken care of in a normal Miranda analysis as to whether it was voluntary or not.
The problem here is that the--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, but what we're trying to determine is, What do you consider in determining whether he has... a reasonable person initiating--

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --Right, and I--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --further discussion?

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --I think you could say that all of those voluntariness factors should be looked at, in terms of initiation, although I just think the analysis would be exactly the same as if you were asking whether he made a voluntary waiver, that it's the same voluntary... voluntariness analysis.
Now, in the--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, I'm not so sure, because a voluntary waiver is measured against a Miranda warning.
And, by definition here, you don't have a Miranda warning, because we're asking about "whether initiation".
So, it seems to me there's a threshold inquiry of voluntariness to determine whether or not there was a voluntary initiation, and that that... it does not comprehend or require a Miranda warning.
Otherwise, you're double counting.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --But you never... there's never... first of all, he had gotten a Miranda warning, initially; and that was when he said he wanted to see a lawyer.
That was... that had happened.
Secondly, whenever there's an initiation case, you've never had another Miranda warning before the initiation.
And what the police did here--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: I agree with that.
But I want... what I think the Court is trying to find is some explanation of the threshold test for determining whether or not there was a voluntary initiation.
Now, I think we agree... or at least I agree... that there shouldn't be any Miranda warnings required.
That doesn't go into the mix.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --But--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Any new Miranda warning.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --Right, but I... still, the... there has been, already, an... a Miranda warning.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: But, still, the question should be broken down into two parts.

The... as the Court said, in Oregon against Bradshaw, you have to... it's useful, at least, to separate the question of initiation, which is a more limited question, from the broader question of voluntariness of a waiver--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But, Mr.--

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --or voluntariness.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --Feldman, do you agree that the State had the burden of proving voluntariness at the second stage?

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And why... and why should we not credit the finding of fact by the... by the trial judge--

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: Well, if the--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --who found it was not voluntary?

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --the middle level... what... Maryland has--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: The middle level--

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --at the middle level--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --said there was no Edwards violation.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --Right.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So, that doesn't contribute anything to the dialogue.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: But the State has argued that actually, given the procedures in this case, the defendant waived his voluntariness claim.
But, in any event, the State... the Maryland Court of Appeals--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, you just told me you agree that the burden was on the--

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --Right.
But--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --State to prove voluntariness.
But I still haven't heard your answer to why we should not credit the finding of fact by the trial judge.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --Well, I'd say... well, two things.
One is, the Maryland Court of Appeals itself explicitly... specifically said that it did not--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I don't care--

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --voluntariness.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --what the Maryland Court of--

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: Not the midlevel--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --Appeals said.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --court, but the--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: The highest court in Maryland also credited the finding.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --No, the... I don't think so.
The highest court in Maryland said,
"We are not going to decide anything about voluntariness, we're only going to decide something about initiation. "

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, in any event, we have a--

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: And--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --a finding of fact by the trial court before us, and I don't... I still don't understand.
From your point of view, why shouldn't we credit that?

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --And I don't think... oh, because I don't... the... that court was relying on a... on the... on the... on the question of initiation.
What... what that court was doing was saying,
"We're going to do a kind of voluntariness lite here and take all the facts that might suggest it's not voluntary, and count them, and say... well, give... those, plus whatever-- "

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You disagree with the--

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --means it's not--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --finding that... the... isn't it... aren't we entitled to give a... some presumption of validity?

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --Yes, but... well, I think that the trial... what the trial court... I think it... no, I don't think so, because I think the trial court was not operating under the correct standard of what it was supposed to... of what initiation consists of.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Because it's a mixed question of law and fact--

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --and not a purely factual--

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --determination.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: If you're going to the standard, which is, I think, the... actually, the difficult question here, what's wrong... should you say... what's wrong with saying... which is what I was pursuing... that, where there is a question that's improper, as there was here, by the police, the only real question is, Is a later initiation "the fruit"?

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: And you say the State has to show it wasn't the fruit.
That would have the virtue of making the law quite consistent here, as it is with Fourth Amendment/Fifth Amendment cases.
That's a well known concept.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --The Court has consistently found, in the Miranda context, that that kind of broad "fruits analysis" doesn't apply in Elstad and--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Why not?

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --other cases.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Why... I understand that--

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: Because--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --there's a lot of language--

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --Because the... the point of the fruits analysis is... has to do with the deterrence function of the Fourth Amendment, which is nonexistent, or much, much reduced, in the Fifth Amendment context, and--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: No, but the standard fruit analysis is when you get something like a statement, and that statement then leads to further evidence.
We're not... I mean, Justice Breyer wasn't using the fruits analysis in that sense.

He was... he was getting at the... at the same question we're all trying to get at: Was the later so called initiation the product of the improper police comment in the first place, or was it voluntary?

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --And I think the Edwards rule is an important, but limited, rule.
And the point of the Edwards rule is to address the particular problem that's caused by a question.
It's not intended to address all of the other problems that can arise in connection with voluntary--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: No, I realize that.
But you concede... I think you concede that the... that the so called initiation has got to be a voluntary initiation.
You don't take the position that it's merely magic words.
Isn't that correct?

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --That's correct.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: All right.
If that is correct, why do we not give some deference to the conclusion of the trial court that this was not voluntary?

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: And--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: You say there was a legal error.
What exactly was the legal error?

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --The problem was that the trial court was not looking at all the factors that you would normally look at to decide voluntariness.
It thought that, in looking at--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: What did it--

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --initiation--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --overlook?
What did it overlook?

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --It overlooked the fact that he had been given the Miranda warnings, that, as far as anybody--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: That's always true in every Edwards case.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --Right.
Well, it's--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: All right.
So--

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --so that's the case.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --that's a wash.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: It overlooked--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: What else did--

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --the fact that--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --it miss?

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --he knew that he had the right to remain silent, and that the particular problem that had been caused by the question--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, Mr. Feldman--

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --which was--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --I have to interrupt.
They did not overlook that he had been given the Miranda warning.
She expressly commented on the fact that an hour and 17 minutes had lapsed since that time.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --Right.
She didn't overlook the fact.
She knew what the facts were.
But she overlooked the significance of that in the analysis.

But, more importantly, she overlooked the significance of the fact that the defendant, at the time that he decided, a half hour later, that he wanted to talk to the police, the police had terminated the earlier questioning and had made it clear to him that they were going to honor his decision whether or not to talk to them without counsel present.
And--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, how--

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --those are--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --was it that she--

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --extremely--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --overlooked that?
I just don't get it.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: They--

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --We... well--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --You know, the evidence is undisputed that one officer made the statement, another officer said no, they left, 30 minutes went by.
What exactly did she overlook?

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --It... she did... what... she did not give the proper weight to those facts, which, in a proper involuntariness analysis, are ones that are important.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You're saying that those facts could not reasonably be found to be... to produce a situation in which the defendant believed he would be hounded to talk, so he said,
"What the heck, I'll talk. "

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Which is what Edwards is directing.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: Right.
And that Edwards was designed to support--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: That no factfinder... and this is mixed fact and law... could reasonably come to that conclusion.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --That--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: When it... when one of the... the last he had heard from the officers was,
"No, he doesn't want to talk. "
"He already asked for a lawyer. "
"We cannot talk to him now. "

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --Coupled--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You're saying no reasonable judge could find that that defendant thought he would be hounded.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --Right.
And the concern of Edwards... as the court has repeatedly explained, the concern of Edwards is that the court... that the police will wear down or badger the defendant.
But once there's... if there's been a--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But it doesn't count--

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --single comment, as can happen--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --Mr. Feldman, it doesn't count as badgering, or the equivalent, that the police... the... walk in, and they present not only the charges, but they present the application for the charges, which shows that the co perpetrator had talked to the police, talked his head off, and put all the blame, at every step on the way, on this defendant?
That did weigh heavily in the trial judge's mind.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --But--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: And is... was that improper to take into account?
How would a reasonable person in this situation feel?
"Would he feel that he was impelled to speak, because the co perpetrator had-- "

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --That... I mean, there's two points I'd like to make about that.
One is, as far as I know under Maryland practice, what they did is consistent with Maryland practice as part of what's normally attendant on taking somebody into custody.
And it's... and it doesn't count as questioning, under Miranda.
And it's a... it's a different problem.

And, secondly, that issue of handing him that charging document... which I think is probably a sound practice, because it lets the defendant know what he's charged with... that practice is one that can happen and can have its influence on a defendant's decision whether or to talk, in any case, and should be considered in a general involuntariness analysis.
But it's not a decisive factor in this case, and it doesn't have to do with the particular concerns of Edwards.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It has nothing to do with whether the defendant thinks he is going to be hounded.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: That's--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It has--

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --correct.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --to do with--

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --with whether--

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --the defendant thinks he will be badgered and badgered until he finally talks.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: That's correct.
They're all--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Which is what Edwards is directed at.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --That's correct.
They're already under--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, Edwards is directed at avoiding badgering, but the issue before us is initiation.
That's not a question of badgering, it's a question of initiation.
And don't the points that Justice Ginsburg raised go to whether the initiation is likely to have been a voluntary initiation?

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: --I don't think they do, because, under the Court's decision in Bradshaw, there's initiation, and then there's always a separate voluntariness inquiry to take care of those problems.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Feldman.
Mr. Ravenell.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court:
It is our position that to allow so called curative measures would lead to police abuses.
If curative measures are allowed, intentional coercive violations should never be allowed to be cured.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: What if it--

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: In fact--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --What if, instead of the half hour or so, 24 hours had passed and they got a call from the defendant, said, "I want to talk now"?
Still, is that... is that initiation on his part?

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --I think that if there had been 24 hours that had passed, then you would... it would be a factor that you would consider in deciding whether the defendant has initiated the conversation.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Okay.
So--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Of course, that factor--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --if you can--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --can work the other way.
You would be up here, saying,
"Oh, he had 24 hours. "
"He thought he was going to get the death penalty. "
"He knew the other man was turning on him to implicate him in the murder. "
"His agony was increasing. "
I mean, I... it seems to me the question is whether or not the curative measures were adequate.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: And--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Of course, you know, we can play the game... 5 minutes, 20 minutes--

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --Right.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --30 minutes.
We know that.
But, it seems to me, when 30 minutes passed here, there were curative measures.
Now, you say, at the outset, there can never be a... curative measures.
That... I don't think you have anything to... any support for that in the case law.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: I certainly believe that the support is, in Edwards versus Arizona, that there should not be a cure unless the defendant himself initiates the contact.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: A cure--

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: So, I think there is.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --A cure of--

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: And if there is--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --I would have thought--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Sorry, go on.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --Sure.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --I would have thought you would have said, then, 24 hours doesn't make a difference.
If there can never be a cure, if there's a violation because the question from Reese constitutes interrogation, and you're telling us there's no cure, it doesn't matter how long it is.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: Yes, I think what I'm... with all due respect, I think what I'm telling the Court is that the practice should be, as it has been the last 25 years, that you do not allow cures of Edwards versus Arizona by the police intentionally violating one's rights and then attempting to cure it.
But, if this Court finds that there can be a cure, we want to participate in what would be a proper cure.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: A cure of what?
That's what--

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: Of a violation.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --it seems to me, a lot of this discussion has come down to.
What are you curing?
Are you curing involuntariness of the confession, or are you curing the police badgering?

I thought that we were just trying to cure the badgering and then let the voluntariness of the confession be decided as voluntariness is normally decided, for which purpose you would take into account that he's been... erroneously said he was charged with murder, or whatever.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: I disagree with Your Honor on... for two reasons.
First, I think that, as several members have... certainly have said so far, that we should focus on whether there was a voluntary initiation.
That has to be considered.
Secondly, I've heard mentioned several times that Edwards only deals with badgering.

I commit... commend this Court to Illinois... Smith versus Illinois... and Minnick versus Mississippi, where this Court has said that Edwards is not only about badgering, but the Court said it's about overreaching by the police, whether it's explicit or subtle.
So, it's not badgering, only.
And when the Petitioner says that Edwards is only about badgering, this Court has said that it's about more than badgering.
It is whether there is overreaching by the police officers that is subtle, that is intentional, that is in deliberate... that is deliberate, any overreaching--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --that causes--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Well, assuming--

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --the person--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --there was--

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --to give up his rights.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --assuming there was overreaching on the part of Officer Reese, my question is, Is there any circumstance in which that overreaching can be cured?
And I thought your answer is that, yes, that with the sufficient passage of time, it can be cured.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: No, with all due respect, Your Honor, that was not my answer.
My answer is that... and I will tell Your Honor that I will not change that position... it should never be allowed to be cured.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: So, once Officer--

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: But--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --once Officer Reese made his comment, there was no circumstance, even a week, a month... relatives come in and say,
"We think you ought to talk. "
no intervening circumstance... once there is that one sentence of overreaching, he can never initiate contact... discussion with--

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --The better--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --the police.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --In my opinion, the better policy, the better practice, is that there should not be.
Now--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You're not helping--

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --if the--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --defendants, you know.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --if I--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: In some cases, you are not helping defendants.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --Well--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Sometimes, a defendant, after he talks to his relatives, might conclude,
"Boy, you know, I'd better cooperate with the police and get a lesser sentence. "
But you're saying that can't happen.
Once--

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --In my--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --once the police make a misstatement, he can never come forward and say, "I want to confess".

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --In my 20 years of trial practice, I have never found it to be at the defendant's best interest to communicate with the police without counsel.
I have--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Ravenell--

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --never found it to be--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --you are defending a judgment that no court in Maryland, as far as I know, ever made.
All of the courts thought that the law was, yes, the taint of an improper question by the police can be removed.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --Correct.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: So, let's take the case as it comes to us.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: Sure.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: The taint can be removed.
That is the law.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Accepting that to be the law, what, in your judgment, would it take to remove the taint +/?
the taint here being the statement that Office Reese made.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: I'll be happy to participate in that conversation.
And this is how we believe that taint can be cured, if at all.
Number one, you put the suspect back in the position that he was in before the violation occurred.
How do you do that?
This is a violation of a right to counsel.
Not a right to remain silent; a right to counsel.
The suspect asked for counsel.
The best way to cure it is, give him counsel.
How else do you cure it?
You tell him that he no longer...
"We were wrong when we told you, you face the death penalty. "

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Suppose--

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: "You do not face the death penalty. "

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --suppose, again, we do not accept that position.
You need another fallback position in our... in order to argue the case before us.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: I don't agree that I need another fallback position, because I believe that if the Court finds that right to counsel... giving him counsel is not enough, other things I'm about to tell the Court, I think, will also be a factor.
For example, telling the defendant that he, in fact, does not face the death penalty.

Very interestingly, this Court... and the Seibert case, in fact, Justice Kennedy's opinion, said that one of the things you consider is, when there is a violation of the right to Miranda rights, you tell the suspect,
"That was an improper violation of your right. "
"That statement may not be admissible-- "

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, Johns--

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --"# against you".

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --Johns, in effect, did that here.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: We disagree.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Certainly, one of the best curative devices is immediate correction from a superior.
And that is exactly what happened here.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: Interestingly, what Your Honor said in the Seibert case is that when... and, in fact, the plurality opinion... when you give an alleged cure in the midst of the violation, the defendant misses it.
So, giving this alleged cure in the midst of the violation creates the problem.
What you need to do is--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: So, you think you'd have a stronger case if Johns hadn't corrected Reese?

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --I think that... I think--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: That's--

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --what we would have--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --But--

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --is a stronger--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --that's a--

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --case.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --far stretch.
It's--

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: No.
I think the case would be proper if Johns did certain things.
One is, give him counsel.
Now, I understand the Court says,
"Maybe we won't go that far. "
But, if you're not going to give him counsel, what else can you do?
You can certainly tell him that the comment by Officer Reese was improper,
"We will honor your right to an attorney. "
"What Officer Reese said was wrong. "
As we point out in our brief, there was never a time when Detective Johns spoke to Blake directly and made any efforts to clarify, or even resolve, the alleged... the violation.
In fact, Detective--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --Johns--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --Well, you don't want the--

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --says--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --you don't want the officer talking to Blake directly.
I thought that would be another violation.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --No.
No.
Now that there is a violation, you have to cure it.
You have to cure it.
And the only way to cure it is for someone to speak to him.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: But it seems--

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: One of the things--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --to me that it's a bit much to say that the problem is that the... he didn't talk to Blake directly, because that gets into another extended dialogue with the defendant that the defendant has not initiated.
It seems it's much better, in the defendant's presence, to do what Johns did here, which is to rebuke Reese for the interrogation.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --With all due respect, I couldn't disagree more, because I think what has to be is that there has to be a direct comment to the suspect so that the suspect understands that this violation occurred,
"It was a violation of your right, and we, the police, will not countenance what Reese did. "
"And here is what we will do. "
"We will get you counsel, if you wish to have counsel. "
"You are not facing the death penalty, young 17-year-old sitting in a cell in your underwear. "
"That is not correct. "
"Here is what we can do for you. "
"We will. "
--in fact, as this Court suggests in the plurality opinion and Seibert, you change location.
You change the interrogator.
You give him time.
As this Court said... in fact, Justice Scalia's... maybe dicta in McNeil said... you look at a lapse of time.
You consider that there is a break in time.
All of those factors may be... if all of those things were done, then you could become... begin to move closer to putting Blake back in the position--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --that he was in before.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --what about just simple thing like this, that there is an implication in what Reese said, that he listens to in his cell,
"I guess you'd... he'll want to talk to us now, huh? "
The implication is that he faces death, and he'll be better off by talking to them without a lawyer.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: And--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So, suppose Johns had said to the defendant,
"Mr. Blake, I want to tell you something. "
"My colleague here has implied that you will be better off, because of the death possibility, in talking to us without a lawyer. "
"We want to tell you, that isn't true. "
"There is no way that you'll be better off talking to us without a lawyer. "
"You will be at least equally, from your point of view, as well off if you talk to a lawyer. "
Now, that might have cured it, I guess.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --I think that if that was done, then we are moving in the right direction.
But--
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --The right direction would be to say, "Please don't talk to us".

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: The right direction would be--
[Laughter]
I would... I would... as Mr. Blake's attorney, I would have appreciated that.
Now, I will tell the Court that I believe that when you add those factors, you really do get closer to curing what we think should not be cured.
Several things this Court said earlier... and I think is correct, from some of the members of the Court... is that we have to give deference to the trial court's finding.

The Government would have you pay no attention to the trial court's finding when the trial court heard Officer Reese... in fact, heard Officer Reese sit on the witness stand and lie under oath... the court found that Officer Reese was not worthy of belief.
Not only did he violate Mr. Blake's right, he then sat on the witness stand and lied about it.

Now, do we want to encourage that kind of police abuse, where the police will abuse the rights of someone, then sit on the witness stand and lie, and then we say... well, the trial judge, who had a chance to observe the demeanor, to watch the witnesses, trial judge, Judge North, who is actually present here, and who had a chance to observe each witness testify--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Counsel, there's no dispute about the historical facts found by the judge.
Everybody agrees this is the dialogue that took place, this is the time that it took place.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --Right.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Those are factual questions.
It's a very different question of what the significance of that is under the Edwards initiation rule.
So, it's not an issue of deference to the trial court judge.
We know what the facts are.
We're deferring to those findings of fact.
It's a question of what the legal significance is.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: And what the Chief Justice says was true in Bradshaw and in Edwards and in Elstad.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: I will ask--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: All questions, which were mixed questions of law and fact, where this Court took the words, took the facts, and made a rule.
And that's this case.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --I will direct the Court to two cases, Salve Regina College versus Russell, 499 U.S. 225, where this Court said the following,

"Deferential review of mixed facts... mixed questions of law and fact is warranted where it appears that the District Court is better positioned than the appellate court to decide the issue in question, or that probing appellate scrutiny is... will not contribute to the clarity of legal doctrine. "
The Court further said, in Miller versus--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Well, just to... stop there.
Why is the trial court better suited to apply the Edwards rule to a set of facts that we would... we accept based on deference to the factfinder?

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --I find that interesting, Your Honor, because the Court did the same thing Elstad.
This Court, in fact, gave every deference to the trial court's finding in Elstad.

So, there's absolutely no reason why this Court would not give the same deferential treatment to Judge North's decision, when Judge North, just as the trial judge in Elstad, got a chance to observe the witnesses who testified, and found that that violation of Elstad's right was not intentional, that it was, kind of, a good faith violation.
That had an impact.
And, in fact, in Seibert, the Court again made reference to that, and, in Justice O'Connor's dissent, made reference to that.
So, it is clear that this Court has given deference... clear deference, on every the... one of the cases I've mentioned in the past, to a trial court's finding.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, are you--

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: There is no reason--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --arguing that--

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --to be different here.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --are you arguing that trial court, even though there's agreement... understanding on most of the historical facts, is still in a better position to make the judgment call as to whether it was voluntary or not?

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: Yes, I am.
And I will point the Court to Miller versus Fenton, 478 U.S. 104, where this Court said,
"Equally clear, an issue does not lose its factual character merely because its resolution is dispositive of the ultimate constitutional question. "
This Court has made clear that you give deference to the trial judge's findings, even if it may have an impact on the ultimate resolution, even where it is a mixed question of fact and law.
And that's all we ask for in this case.
I believe, Your Honor, that when we consider that... in this particular matter, the evidence is clear that Mr. Blake was responding to the comments by Office Reese.
And the trial court made that finding.
The trial court made a finding that Office Reese's comment was intended to elicit a response.
Same thing this Court has said in Innis.
When you get to the next step, the question is, What that interrogation?
The trial court made a factual finding it was interrogation.
In fact, Petitioner concedes it was interrogation.
Next step was, Was it a response, or was it new initiation of a new conversation, by Blake?
The trial court found that it was a response by Mr. Blake to the comments by Officer Reese.
The trial court also made a finding that there, in fact, was no cure.
That factual finding was given deference by the Court of Appeals.
The Court of Appeals considered several things.
It said you should consider the attenuation.
This Court said you should consider change in interrogation, location of interrogation... change in the interrogator... excuse me... change in the location.
And I believe that we add the fact that there would have been no further advice to the... to the suspect that he did not face the death penalty.
Parties agree here.
In fact, in the SG's, Solicitor General's, brief, on page 25, they say,
"If there has been any intentional coercive violation, there should be not be a cure. "
The trial court found that the act of Office Johns was intentional.
I don't think anyone... anyone, even under... in... under any standard of review... could find that Officer John... Officer Reese's... excuse me... comment was not intentional.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: What was the quote from the SG's brief?
I didn't--

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: Page 25.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --And what did they say?

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: If I may--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Maybe they said that.
I'd be surprised if they said that.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --I would be happy to read on...
"Police officers who engage in interrogation-- "

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Can you tell us--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --where you're reading from?

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --I'm sorry.
Page 25 of the SG's brief.
I'm reading.
"Police officers who engage in interrogation after a suspect has invoked his right to counsel also run the risk of a judicial finding that any statement given was coerced. "
as we have here.
If I may continue,
"In that event, the initial statement would be unusable for any purpose-- "

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Yes, if there was a judicial finding that any statement given was--

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --Which is--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --coerced.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --Which is what we have in the trial court finding, that there is... and, in fact, it was coerced.
The trial judge made a finding that this was an intentionally coercive act by Officer Reese.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: We're talking about the confession being coerced, that the statement given was coerced--

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --not that his decision to talk to the police was coerced.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: I disagree that if there, in fact, was an initial... if there was, in fact, coercion by the police, that that coercion did not play a part in Mr. Reese... Mr. Blake deciding to speak.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Yes, we're--

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: And, in fact--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --only talking--

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --in State--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --about what the SG has conceded.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: He has conceded that if the... if it is found by the court that the statement given was a--

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_ravenell
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Ravenell
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
